case_name: Swastik Oil Mills Ltd. v. Respondents

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 637 of 1967 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated January 27, 1966 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Application No. 112 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 637 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 27, 1966 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Application No. 112 of 1963.

facts.text: Swastik Oil Mills Ltd. is the appellant and carries on business of manufacturing vegetable oils, soaps and other products, selling in India and exporting outside India.

anchor.surface_text: The Swastik Oil Mills Ltd., appellant, carries on business of manufacturing vegetable oils, soaps and other products and selling them in India as well as exporting them outside India.

facts.text: Appellant was registered as a dealer under Bombay Sales Tax Acts: 1946 (Act 5), 1953 (Act 3), 1959 (Act 51).

anchor.surface_text: It was registered as a dealer under the various Sales Tax Acts in force in Bombay. The first of these Acts was the Bombay Sales Tax Act 5 of 1946, which was replaced by th -Bombay Sales Tax Act 3 of 1953. The third and the latest -Act number in force in Bombay is the Bombay Sales Tax Act 51 of 1959.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to sales tax for periods 1st April 1948 to 31st March 1950 and 1st April 1950 to 31st March 1951 on basis of returns submitted by it.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was assessed to sales tax on its turnover for the periods from 1st April, 1948 to 31st March, 1950, and from 1st April, 1950 to 31st March, 1951 on the basis of Returns of turnover submitted by it.

facts.text: In returns, appellant claimed exemption for turnover of despatches/transfers from Head Office Bombay to depots/branches in other States.

anchor.surface_text: In these Returns, the appellant claimed exemption from tax in respect of the turnover representing the despatches or transfer of goods from its Head Office Bombay, to its various Depots or Branches in other States in India,

facts.text: Appellant claimed exemption for sales in course of inter-State trade after 26th January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and also exemption in respect of sales which were alleged to have taken place in the companyrse of inter-State trade after 26th January, 1950.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer rejected both exemption claims in assessment order dated 2nd January 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer in his order of assessment dated 2nd January, 1954 rejected both these claims.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Assistant Collector of Sales Tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant went up in appeal before the Assistant Collector of Sales Tax,

facts.text: Assistant Collector in appellate order dated 29th October 1956 accepted exemption for despatches to depots/branches in other States, disallowed inter-State sales claim.

anchor.surface_text: who, in his appellate order dated 29th October, 1956, accepted the claim of the appellant in respect of the despatches to its various Depots or Branches in other States in India, but disallowed the claim in respect of the alleged inter-State sales.

facts.text: Assistant Collector reduced tax by Rs. 19,240-15-6 for 1/4/1948-31/3/1950 and Rs. 97,208/- for 1/4/1950-31/3/1951, directed refund.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of partially allowing the claim of the appellant, the Assistant Collector reduced the tax imposed by a sum of Rs. 19,240-15-6 for the period between 1st April, 1948 to 31st March, 1950, and Rs. 97,208/for the second period between 1st April, 1950 to 31st March, 1951, and directed refund of these amounts to the appellant.

facts.text: Revisions filed by appellant against rejection of inter-State sales claim were pending.

anchor.surface_text: The revisions filed by the appellant against the rejection of its claim in respect of inter-State sales were still pending,

facts.text: On 7th January 1963, Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bombay City Division issued notice in Form XXIV under s.31 Bombay Sales Tax Act 1953 to revise suo motu the appellate orders re despatches exemption.

anchor.surface_text: when, on 7th January, 1963, a numberice was issued by the Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bombay City Division, in Form XXIV under section 31 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953, intimating the appellant that he proposed to revise suo motu the appellate orders passed by the Assistant Collector of Sales Tax insofar as he had allowed deduction, in respect of the entire goods despatched to its Branches in other States outside Maharashtra,

facts.text: Notice cited overlooked proviso b to sub-clause ii of Rule 1 under sub-s.3 s.6 Bombay ST Act 1946 as amended by Act 48 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: because, in so doing, he had overlooked the provisions companytained in proviso  b  to sub-clause  ii  of Rule 1 under sub-section  3  of section 6 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946 as amended by the Bombay Sales Tax Amendment Act 48 of 1949.

facts.text: Appellant appeared before Deputy Commissioner, raised objections, requested dropping proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this numberice, the appellant put in appearance before the Deputy Commissioner, who is the respondent in this appeal, and raised several objections against the proposed revisional proceedings, making a request that the proceedings be dropped.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner did not accept request to drop proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Since the respondent did number accept this request,

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Article 226 in Bombay High Court challenging notice dated 7th January 1963, seeking quashing and restraint.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant filed a petition under Article 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Bombay challenging the numberice dated 7th January, 1963, with the prayer that the numberice be quashed and the respondent be restrained from taking any action against the appellant in pursuance thereof.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed by the High Court and,

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate granted by Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: number, on certificate granted by that Court, the appellant has companye up in this appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner is the respondent in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: who is the respondent in this appeal,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that proceedings initiated by Deputy Commissioner are competent, High Court right in refusing writ.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we hold that the proceedings initiated by the Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax against the appellant are number incompetent and the High Court was right in refusing the writ sought by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Act of 1953 was repealed by s. 76 of the Act of 1959

anchor.surface_text: Whenever a power is conferred on an authority to revise an order, the authority is entitled to examine the correctness, legality and propriety of the order and to pass such suitable orders as the authority may think fit in the circumstances of the particular case before it. When exercising such powers, there is no reason why the authority should not be entitled to hold an enquiry or direct an enquiry to be held and, for that purpose, admit additional material.

concepts.interpretation: Revising authority not limited to existing record; can conduct or direct additional enquiry if necessary for just decision, subject to not trenching on other authorities' powers.

anchor.surface_text: Section 22 of the Act of 1946 and s. 31 of the Act of 1953 do not lay down any limitation for exercise of the power of revision by a Deputy Commissioner suo motu, and we are not prepared to accept that any such limitation must be necessarily read in the two Acts.

concepts.interpretation: No implied reasonable time limitation for suo motu revision absent express provision; distinguished from assessment/reassessment limitations.

issues.text: Whether, in exercise of the revisional powers under the Sales Tax Acts of 1946, 1953 or 1959, the Deputy Commissioner could only proceed on the basis of material already on record and was not entitled to institute any enquiry or admit additional material?

anchor.surface_text: The first point urged by learned counsel was that, in exercise of the revisional powers, the Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax, whether acting under the Sales Tax Act of 1946, or of 1953, or of 1959, could only proceed to take action on the basis of the material already present on the record and was not entitled to act on conjecture or to institute any enquiry so as to include additional material in order to judge the correctness of the order sought to be revised.

issues.text: Whether the notice issued in 1963 under the repealed Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953 was invalid and the revisional powers could only be exercised under the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1959 within the prescribed time limit?

anchor.surface_text: The next point urged by learned counsel was that the notice in question was issued on the 7th January, 1963, when the Act of 1959 had already come into force and the Act of 1953 had been repealed, so that if any revisional jurisdiction could be exercised by the Deputy Commissioner, it could only be under the Act of 1959 and not under the Act of 1953.

issues.text: Whether the revisional proceedings were invalid because initiated under section 31 of the 1953 Act instead of section 22 of the 1946 Act?
Whether suo motu revisional proceedings under section 22 of the 1946 Act or section 31 of the 1953 Act are barred by an implied limitation of reasonable time?

anchor.surface_text: The last submission made by Mr. Desai was that, if it be held that the revisional powers are sought to be exercised under the Act of 1946, it should be held that the proceedings sought to be instituted are barred by time, because limitation of a reasonable time, within which the revisional powers are to be exercised, must be implied in the statute itself.

issues.text: Whether the exercise of revisional powers trenches upon the powers of assessment or reassessment under sections 11 and 11A of the 1946 Act?

arguments.claim: The appellate orders passed by the Assistant Collector overlooked the provisions contained in proviso b to sub-clause ii of Rule 1 under sub-section 3 of section 6 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946 as amended, justifying suo motu revision.

anchor.surface_text: because, in so doing, he had overlooked the provisions contained in proviso b to sub-clause ii of Rule 1 under sub-section 3 of section 6 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946 as amended by the Bombay Sales Tax Amendment Act 48 of 1949.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s primarily vested by rule 17 in the assessing officer and is to be exercised subject to certain limitations, and the revising authority will number b

arguments.court_reasoning: Court upholds initiation of revision on this ground as proceedings are competent under relevant provisions.

arguments.claim: In exercise of revisional powers under Sales Tax Acts of 1946, 1953 or 1959, the Deputy Commissioner could only proceed on material already on record and was not entitled to institute enquiry or admit additional material.

anchor.surface_text: The first point urged by learned counsel was that, in exercise of the revisional powers, the Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax, whether acting under the Sales Tax Act of 1946, or of 1953, or of 1959, could only proceed to take action on the basis of the material already present on the record and was not entitled to act on conjecture or to institute any enquiry so as to include additional material in order to judge the correctness of the order sought to be revised.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ers, he will keep within the limitations indicated by this Court in the case cited above. The numberice cannot be quashed or the proceedings restraine

arguments.court_reasoning: Revising authority entitled to examine correctness, legality, propriety and hold enquiry; follows State of Kerala v. M. Cheria Abdulla allowing additional material subject to limitations.

arguments.claim: Notice issued on 7th January 1963 under repealed Bombay Sales Tax Act 1953 is invalid; revisional jurisdiction can only be under Bombay Sales Tax Act 1959 s.57, which is time-barred (more than 5/2 years from 1956 order).

anchor.surface_text: The next point urged by learned counsel was that the notice in question was issued on the 7th January, 1963, when the Act of 1959 had already come into force and the Act of 1953 had been repealed, so that if any revisional jurisdiction could be exercised by the Deputy Commissioner, it could only be under the Act of 1959 and not under the Act of 1953.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.77 of 1959 Act and Bombay General Clauses Act s.7 save prior Acts for pre-appointed day liabilities and proceedings; 1953/1946 provisions continue.

arguments.claim: Proceedings invalid because initiated under s.31 of 1953 Act instead of correct s.22 of 1946 Act.
arguments.court_reasoning: Provisions of s.22(1946) and s.31(1953) are similar; incorrect citation immaterial as jurisdiction exists under s.22.

arguments.claim: Suo motu revisional proceedings under s.22(1946) or s.31(1953) barred by implied limitation of reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: The last submission made by Mr. Desai was that, if it be held that the revisional powers are sought to be exercised under the Act of 1946, it should be held that the proceedings sought to be instituted are barred by time, because limitation of a reasonable time, within which the revisional powers are to be exercised, must be implied in the statute itself.

arguments.court_reasoning: No express or implied time limit in s.22/s.31; distinguishes cases on assessment/reassessment limits; only limits are not trenching on other powers.

arguments.claim: Revising authority has power to hold or direct enquiry and admit additional material when necessary for just decision.

anchor.surface_text: Whenever a power is conferred on an authority to revise an order, the authority is entitled to examine the correctness, legality and propriety of the order and to pass such suitable orders as the authority may think fit in the circumstances of the particular case before it. When exercising such powers, there is no reason why the authority should not be entitled to hold an enquiry or direct an enquiry to be held and, for that purpose, admit additional material.

arguments.claim: Repeal of prior Sales Tax Acts by 1959 Act does not affect ongoing proceedings or powers under saved provisions for pre-1959 periods.
Exercise of revisional powers does not trench on assessment/reassessment powers under s.11/11A as turnover was already assessed and set aside on appeal.
No limitation period applies to suo motu revision under s.22(1946)/s.31(1953) as none prescribed.

holdings.text: In exercise of revisional powers under the Bombay Sales Tax Acts of 1946, 1953 or 1959, the Deputy Commissioner is entitled to hold an enquiry or direct an enquiry to be held and admit additional material, subject to limitations of not trenching on powers of other authorities.

anchor.surface_text: Whenever a power is conferred on an authority to revise an order, the authority is entitled to examine the correctness, legality and propriety of the order and to pass such suitable orders as the authority may think fit in the circumstances of the particular case before it. When exercising such powers, there is no reason why the authority should not be entitled to hold an enquiry or direct an enquiry to be held and, for that purpose, admit additional material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revising authority examines correctness, legality, propriety; can admit additional material if necessary for just decision; follows State of Kerala v. M. Cheria Abdulla; notice based on overlooked proviso, not conjecture.

holdings.text: Notice issued under repealed Bombay Sales Tax Act 1953 in 1963 is valid; revisional powers continue under saved provisions of 1946/1953 Acts for pre-1959 periods via s.77 of 1959 Act and Bombay General Clauses Act s.7.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Savings clause s.77(1)(a) continues prior Acts for levy/assessment etc. relating to pre-appointed day; General Clauses Act s.7 preserves proceedings/remedies unaffected by repeal.

holdings.text: Initiation of proceedings under s.31 of 1953 Act instead of correct s.22 of 1946 Act is immaterial as provisions similar and jurisdiction exists under s.22.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.48(2)/49(1) of 1953 saved 1946 provisions for prior liabilities; incorrect citation does not invalidate as substantive power under correct section available.

holdings.text: No express or implied limitation of reasonable time applies to suo motu revisional powers under s.22 of 1946 Act or s.31 of 1953 Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of time bar in texts; distinguishes assessment/reassessment limits; only limits are those not to trench on other powers per Cheria Abdulla.

holdings.text: Exercise of revisional powers does not trench upon assessment/reassessment powers under ss.11/11A of 1946 Act, as turnover was originally assessed and exempted on appeal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Turnover assessed initially by STO, set aside in appeal; s.11A for escaped turnover inapplicable; revision corrects appellate error without encroaching.

holdings.text: Proceedings initiated by Deputy Commissioner are competent; High Court correctly refused writ under Art.226.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative resolution of all issues upholding validity of suo motu revision on overlooked proviso to s.6(3) Rule 1(b)(ii) of 1946 Act.

precedents.citation: State of Andhra Pradesh v. T. G. Lakshmaiah Setty Sons, 12 S.T.C. 663

anchor.surface_text: In support of this proposition, learned companynsel referred us to a decision of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in State of Andhra Pradesh v. T. G. Lakshmaiah Setty Sons. 1 . In that case, the Deputy Commissioner, in exercising the revisional jurisdiction, was found by the High Court to have based his assessment on guess-work, and the Court held that this companyjecture companyld number be a justification for seeking to revise the order of the assessing authority.

precedents.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v T G Lakshmaiah Setty Sons
precedents.cited_proposition: Revising authority cannot base revision on conjecture or guess-work and must confine to existing record without new enquiry
precedents.cited_holding: conjecture could not be a justification for seeking to revise the order of the assessing authority. It must be made clear that he has no jurisdiction to travel beyond the record that is available to the assessing authority

precedents.citation: The State of Kerala v. M. Cheria Abdulla and Company, 1965 1 S.C.R. 601

anchor.surface_text: This principle has been clearly recognised by this Court in The State of Kerala v. M. Cheria Abdulla and Company 1 . In that case, sub- section  2  of s. 12 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939, which came up for interpretation, empowered the Deputy Commissioner, suo motu or under certain circumstances on an application, to call for and examine the record of any order passed or proceeding recorded under the provisions of that Act by any officer subordinate to him, for the purpose of satisfying himself as to the legality or propriety of such order, or as to the regularity of such proceeding, and to pass such order with respect thereto as he thought fit.

precedents.case_name: State of Kerala v M Cheria Abdulla and Company
precedents.cited_proposition: Revising authority can hold or direct enquiry and admit additional material even outside the record
precedents.cited_holding: there is nothing in the Act that [...] he cannot make or direct any further enquiry. [...] can never make enquiry outside that record.

precedents.citation: State of Orissa v. Debaki Debi and Others, 15 S.T.C. 153

anchor.surface_text: In support of his proposition that such a limitation must be read by us, Mr. Desai referred to the decision of this Court in the State of Orissa v. Debaki Debi and Others 1 . That case, however, has no relevance at all, because, in the Orissa Sales Tax Act, there was a proviso in general terms laying down that no order assessing the

precedents.case_name: State of Orissa v Debaki Debi and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: Limitation of reasonable time must be implied for exercise of revisional powers

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Narsee Nagsee Co., 31 I.T.R. 164

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Bombay High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1 v. Narsee Nagsee Co.  1  is also similarly inapplicable. In that case, section 11 of the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947, which had no limitation prescribed for an order of assessment, was held to be governed by the 4 years period of limitation which was prescribed under s. 14 for issue of a notice for reassessment.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City v Narsee Nagsee Co
precedents.cited_proposition: Absence of express limitation implies limitation from analogous provisions like reassessment period

precedents.citation: Manordas Kalidas v. V. V. Tatke, 11 S.T.C. 87

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, Mr. Desai relied on a decision of the Bombay High Court in Manordas Kalidas v. V. V. Tatke 1 . The decision in that case also related to this very Act of 1946, but the point to be kept in view is that in that case, the revisional power was sought to be exercised in respect of the original assessment order passed by the Sales Tax Officer under S. 11 of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Manordas Kalidas v V V Tatke
precedents.cited_proposition: Revisional jurisdiction must be exercised within reasonable time analogous to reassessment limitation

precedents.citation: Bisesar House v. State of Bombay, 9 S.T.C. 654

anchor.surface_text: after referring to its two decisions in Bisesar House v. State of Bombay  2 and Commr. of Income-tax v. Narsee Nagsee Co. held - ,,In neither of those two cases, revisional powers were sought to be exercised, but the principle of those cases must, in our judgment, apply for the same reasons to the exercise of revisional jurisdiction, and that jurisdiction must be exercised w ithin a reasonable period, and the yard-stick of reasonableness will be the period prescribed for re-assessment.

precedents.case_name: Bisesar House v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle of limitation applies to analogous situations

precedents.citation: Commr. of Income-tax v. Narsee Nagsee Co., 31 I.T.R. 164

precedents.case_name: Commr of Income-tax v Narsee Nagsee Co
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle of limitation applies to analogous situations

precedents.citation: K. M. Cheria Abdulla Co., 1965 1 S.C.R. 601

anchor.surface_text: the correct principle that should have been applied in that case is the principle mentioned by us earlier laid down in K. M. Cheria Abdulla Co. 4 . The revision should have been held to be incompetent on the ground that the power was sought to be exercised for assessment of escaped turnover which had not been assessed at all at the initial stage of -assessment under s. 11 and proceedings under s. 11A could have been competently initiated for bringing that turnover to tax.

precedents.cited_proposition: Limitations on revisional power: cannot trench on powers of other authorities

precedents.citation: Maharaj Kumar Kamal Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa, 35 I.T.R. 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference, in this connection, was also made to a decision of this Court in Maharaj Kumar Kamal Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa 1 , in which the Court dealt with a case of an assessee whose income to the extent of Rs. 93,604/representing interest on arrears of rent was omitted to be brought to assessment by the Income-tax Officer.

precedents.case_name: Maharaj Kumar Kamal Singh v Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar and Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Escaped assessment can be reassessed under reassessment provisions even after remand order

anchor.surface_text: Whenever a power is conferred on an authority to revise an order, the authority is entitled to examine the correctness, legality and propriety of the order and to pass such suitable orders as the authority may think fit in the circumstances of the particular case before it. When exercising such powers, there is no reason why the authority should not be entitled to hold an enquiry or direct an enquiry to be held and, for that purpose, admit additional material.

For these reasons, we hold that the proceedings initiated by the Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax against the appellant are number incompetent and the High Court was right in refusing the writ sought by the appellant.
